Tim,  I enjoy your channel/videos.  I have a video suggestion/question or two for you.  1) Skylab, the forgotten missions. I'm old enough to remember seeing men on the moon, and was a space nerd back then. I was glad to see the news that NASA was putting Skylab into orbit. But Youtube and the world wide web really didn't exist back then, so Skylab news was few and far between. So my question to you is: Could you give a history of it's inception, design, launch, missions, and overall history. I've been scouring youtube, and found only a few videos, none of which are all that encompassing.  2) "Cool stuff still up there." What happened to all the stuff that's been launched, and what cool stuff is still up there. Like Snoopy, and other things. I'd love to see a episode of the top 10 things still up there, with a short story of what it is,  how it came to be "still up there" , etcetera.  Just a couple things.   BTW... watch the Christmas gift episode just recently and am currently enjoying Kerbal Space Program.

I am usually not a big commenter on youtube videos, but I love your channel and have seen many of your videos. I really felt compelled to reach out to you on this one after watching the first 2 minutes. I had a best friend growing up, but I ended up becoming better friends with his dad (Pops) than him after we grew up. Pops was like a second father to me and we lost him a few years back now, but I still think of him and our many deep conversations very often. It still hits me just as hard now when I think about the day we lost him as it did that day and I don't think it will ever get any easier. Nothing wrong with showing emotion, you have nothing to apologize for my man. Praying for Tom, Josh, Ron, the whole Parks family and for you Tim. God Bless!

Condolences Tim, you're such a wonderful person coming back here and diggin in to join us for a launch and then handing off the proceeds to loved ones in need. No need to make any apologies or anything like that. I'm a bit time-delayed but I still enjoy spending the time with you and the chat scroll. Every time. :o) I'll virtual hug you. HUG

I always come here to feel squiggly and tingles for these launches, and this one sure delivered, what with the 50th landing milestone, and that fantastic plume! I hope to be in town some day for a Heavy or even Starship, that would be really something to feel the monster come alive from miles away. And SpaceX sure, they're definitely winning at media, but also Rocket Lab I really like. And yeah even ULA and Blue Origin get me going a bit. Every one of them has found a bit of a different way forward to assemble the future, and ... yeah it makes me squggly and tingles. --- But oh man, I was really quite sad for the Astra team when I saw they didn't make it work for the contest. Those folks are innovating in a whole new direction and taking on extraordinary engineering risks that no one else dares. I really wanted to see them meet that challenge and take home the prize and the pride for it.
We love ya my guy <3 do what ever you need to feel better we will always be here for you

Your Diverse Content is amazing. You provide uncommon and uniquely illuminating technical detail most appreciated. Your rocket motor video - excellent!  Another technical detail- Weld joint integrity and weld joint design seem to have caused Starship problems. A weld joint can be a stress concentrator. Perfect welds are expensive and almost impossible  in sub-optimal conditions. I wonder if lap weld joints might spread out the load, add some redundancy, and reduce heat distortion.  The doubled area of the  lap joint could be designed to create a toughened transition area in a high stress zone. However the welding joint problems are solved, It would be great when they are that you would make a video about the learning steps to create a reliable structure for the welded Starship hull. It reminds me of Liberty ship construction in early WW2. They started out with riveted joints, and by the end of the war ended up welded joints. There were some costly failures in the learning curve. Thank you for the great work.

Thanks Tim - appreciated.  It was 4 in the morning here, so I didn't stay up for it, so it was a nice surprise to find your 'live' stream when I got up this morning.  Sorry to hear about your friend's dad, unfortunately life sucks at times, but we get through it.  You seem to be going through one of those phases where everything seems to happen/change all at once - it's weird how this seems to happen.  It's stressful at the time, but looking back you'll find that it was actually a good thing - the re-boot your life needed.  All the best for the future, and don't worry about videos - we can wait.  It's about time that Youtubers (and their audiences) broke away from the treadmill of producing regular videos, anyway - it only leads to staleness and, eventually, burnout.  The idea that audiences will drift away if you don't produce regular content is a myth, and a dangerous one, it needs to be debunked.
Thanx for letting us know that the pointy end is up.  Good call.

1:07:56 Indeed, the top right curve is the boostback burn. The boostback burn reverses the HORIZONTAL component of its motion, the vertical component of its motion follows a ballistic path still going upwards, with Earth's gravity slowing it down and then pulling it back down. The re-entry burn later cancels out much of the acquired descent velocity. Such plumes are normally seen due to illumination by sunlight at dawn or dusk, but here it's unusual in that it doesn't illuminate more of the exhaust plumes of both the first and second stages, so perhaps this is self-illumination by the first and second stage motors. It is a long time exposure, of course, so I wonder whether viewers on the ground saw anything like this instantly. The usual dawn or dusk solar-illuminated plume displays can be seen in their full glory by eye. However, the amount of plume seen in both the first and second stage on-board cameras seemed quite unusual for a night launch, so I wonder if there wasn't a beam of sunlight present around staging, perhaps governed by cloud configurations on the horizon at "sunrise".
Vale Ron.. now with the stars

On John Kraus' awesome photo, I think the left is the very end of stage 1 firing, the gap is MECO, and the arc that continues to bottom right is stage 2 ignition and burn. The streak that flips and shoot to the top of the image is stage 1 doing boostback burn.
